text: Missing “Required fields” Missing/renamed “container” API entry points return data container, example, data/get_data -> results (holds main data) data/list_collections -> results (holds counts); request_id (holds request id) data/list_requests -> requests (holds details individual requests) “containers” change names, package break.

title: Chapter 1 - Introduction
text: NatureCounts website hosted managed Birds Canada, Canada’s leading scientific non-government organization dedicated increasing understanding, appreciation conservation wild birds habitats . Birds Canada specializes citizen science long-term monitoring programs using partnership-based model. Citizen science found cost-effective way monitor bird populations across large geographic areas. Canada, 16,000 volunteers currently involved Birds Canada’s programs. Launched January 2008, NatureCounts first Canadian node Avian Knowledge Network. serves online data dissemination portal facilitate collection, management sharing biological data. NatureCounts hosts hundreds datasets, representing well 140 million occurrences birds. include virtually Birds Canada’s monitoring initiatives, Breeding Bird Atlases, eBird Canada, Marsh Monitoring Program, Nocturnal Owl Surveys, well many major initiatives Birds Canada contributes capacity (e.g., Canadian Migration Monitoring Program, HawkCount Raptor Population Index, Monarch Knowledge Network, Breeding Bird Survey, Christmas Bird Count, Project FeederWatch). can NatureCounts webportal? can explore data resources NatureCounts via interactive maps allow view distribution bird populations time year across variety different sources. can obtain visualize information long term population trends Canadian birds. can explore individual species pattern distribution species richness location via dynamically generated summary tables graphs. Finally, much observational data can downloaded personal research!

NatureCounts five Levels Data Access, define dataset can used. levels set individually dataset, consultation various partners data custodians involved. Level 0: restricted (archival ) Level 1: archival , metadata visible Level 2: data used visualizations Level 3: data available third parties request Level 4: data shared external portals available request Level 5: open access contributing members NatureCounts complete authority use data provided, can withhold data time party application. users NatureCounts data must clearly acknowledge contribution members making data available. dataset comes Data Sharing Policy defines various conditions data usage. can view Data Access Level collection NatureCounts Datasets page using metadata function (see akn_level): can create stand alone table metadata table using similar syntax retrieve metadata specific set collections based project_id, can index ‘collections’ dataframe.

title: Data Access
text: downloads naturecounts require free NatureCounts account (sign ). data hosted NatureCounts immediately available users. Different data sets different access levels (also called akn_levels). full description different levels available NatureCounts site. Briefly, five levels R package naturecounts can potentially access three levels (users). Data access level 5 considered public data available users. Data access levels 4 3 private/semi-public projects/collections. access data must request access (see Requesting Access, ). Data access level 2 visible counts returned nc_count() metadata returned meta_collections() , etc., downloadable nc_data_dl() naturecounts R package without special permissions. Data access level 1 visible naturecounts R package without special permissions.

code: library(naturecounts) library(dplyr) library(lubridate) boreal_chickadee_df <- nc_data_dl(species = 14320, collection = "BBS", verbose = FALSE,                                   username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") con <- nc_data_dl(species = 14320, collection = "BBS", sql_db = "boreal_chickadee",                    verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") boreal_chickadee_db <- tbl(con, "naturecounts") con <- DBI::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), dbname = "boreal_chickadee.nc") boreal_chickadee_db <- tbl(con, "naturecounts") boreal_chickadee_df <- collect(boreal_chickadee_db) boreal_chickadee_df <- format_dates(boreal_chickadee_df, overwrite = TRUE) con <- format_dates(con) boreal_chickadee_db <- tbl(con, "naturecounts") filter(boreal_chickadee_df, is.na(date)) |>   select(survey_year, survey_month, survey_day, date) ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ##   survey_year survey_month survey_day date   ##         <int>        <int>      <int> <date> ## 1        2001           NA         NA NA     ## 2        2007           NA         NA NA     ## 3        2007           NA         NA NA     ## 4        1987           NA         NA NA

title: Zero-filling data
text: zero-filling requires species reported (can know species observed, wasn’t reported?), format_zero_fill return error records valid. Therefore, first thing need limit data SamplingEventIdentifiers species recorded. Note AllSpeciesReported may always strictly true, bird identification events (e.g., Christmas Bird Counts) may report bird species, probably report mammalian species, plants, etc. vice versa. Now can fill species missing sampling events.  might helpful use common names, process zero-filling, extra columns removed.
code: rc_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc) ## Error: Column 'AllSpeciesReported' must be present and 'Yes' rc_all_species <- filter(rc, AllSpeciesReported == "Yes") count(rc_all_species, AllSpeciesReported) ##   AllSpeciesReported   n ## 1                Yes 173 rc_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_all_species) ##  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric head(rc_filled) ##   SamplingEventIdentifier species_id ObservationCount ## 1     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252456                1 ## 2     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252491                0 ## 3     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252494                0 ## 4     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252456                2 ## 5     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252491                0 ## 6     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252494                0 ggplot(data = rc_filled, aes(x = factor(species_id), fill = ObservationCount > 0)) +   geom_bar(position = "dodge") +   labs(title = "Number of sampling events the species was observed")

title: Zero-filling data
text: Sampling events aren’t way zero-filling data. Perhaps ’re interested whether species /observed particular location. message summarizing multiple observations means multiple observations per utm_square. example isn’t large enough slowed much, larger examples, can much faster simplify dataset first. Now zero-fill data set, get zero-filled, aggregated dataset.
code: rc_loc_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_all_species,                                    by = "utm_square") ##  - Consider summarizing multiple observations per set of 'by' before zero-filling to increase speed ##  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric head(rc_loc_filled) ##   utm_square species_id ObservationCount ## 1    18TTR94     252456                1 ## 2    18TTR94     252491                0 ## 3    18TTR94     252494                0 ## 4    18TUR04     252456                1 ## 5    18TUR04     252456                1 ## 6    18TUR04     252456                1 rc_sum <- rc_all_species |>   group_by(utm_square, species_id, AllSpeciesReported) |>   summarize(ObservationCount = sum(as.numeric(ObservationCount), na.rm = TRUE),             .groups = "drop") head(rc_sum) ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   utm_square species_id AllSpeciesReported ObservationCount ##   <chr>           <int> <chr>                         <dbl> ## 1 18TTR94        252456 Yes                               1 ## 2 18TUR04        252456 Yes                              67 ## 3 18TUR04        252491 Yes                              46 ## 4 18TUR04        252494 Yes                              22 ## 5 18TUR17        252456 Yes                               1 ## 6 18TUR27        252491 Yes                               1 rc_sum_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_sum, by = "utm_square") head(rc_sum_filled) ##   utm_square species_id ObservationCount ## 1    18TTR94     252456                1 ## 2    18TTR94     252491                0 ## 3    18TTR94     252494                0 ## 4    18TUR04     252456               67 ## 5    18TUR04     252491               46 ## 6    18TUR04     252494               22

title: Zero-filling data
text: default format_zero_fill() adds 0’s ObservationCount column, can specify column zero fill. example, wanted deal Presence/Absence create new presence column zero-fill column.
code: rc_presence <- rc_all_species |>   select(species_id, AllSpeciesReported, ObservationCount, SamplingEventIdentifier) |>   mutate(presence = if_else(as.numeric(ObservationCount) > 0, TRUE, FALSE)) head(rc_presence) ##   species_id AllSpeciesReported ObservationCount SamplingEventIdentifier ## 1     252456                Yes                6      RCBIOTABASE-5553-1 ## 2     252491                Yes                1      RCBIOTABASE-5553-1 ## 3     252456                Yes                2      RCBIOTABASE-5547-1 ## 4     252456                Yes                1      RCBIOTABASE-5546-1 ## 5     252494                Yes                1      RCBIOTABASE-6235-1 ## 6     252491                Yes                3      RCBIOTABASE-5545-1 ##   presence ## 1     TRUE ## 2     TRUE ## 3     TRUE ## 4     TRUE ## 5     TRUE ## 6     TRUE rc_presence_filled <- format_zero_fill(rc_presence, fill = "presence") ##  - Converted 'fill' column (presence) from logical to numeric head(rc_presence_filled) ##   SamplingEventIdentifier species_id presence ## 1     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252456        1 ## 2     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252491        0 ## 3     RCBIOTABASE-10008-1     252494        0 ## 4     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252456        1 ## 5     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252491        0 ## 6     RCBIOTABASE-10015-1     252494        0

title: Mapping Observations
text: ’re going take quick look spatial distribution using ggplot2 ggspatial get basemaps. First let’s get idea many distinct points (often multiple observations recorded location). 1263 sites 7211 observations. Next let’s convert data spatial data can plot spatially (.e. make map!). Note ’re using CRS EPSG code 4326 ’s reflects unprojected, GPS data lat/lon. First omit NAs sf data frames missing locations. Now ’re ready make map distribution observations. ’ll use baselayer OpenStreetMap add observations.  Let’s count observations site.

title: Mapping Observations
text: want get fancy can also create interactive maps using mapview packages (see also leaflet R package).
code: mapview(house_finches_sf, zcol = "survey_year", at = seq(1965, 2005, by = 10),         map.types = "Esri.WorldImagery")

title: Mapping Observations
text: complex, detailed maps, can use variety spatial data files layer data maps area. ’ll get outlines Canada ’s Provinces Territories rnaturalearth.  Let’s add observations (note data transformed match projection first layer, canada data).  can also focus Alberta  Perhaps see observations distributed among Alberta’s Bird Conservation Regions (BCRs). First ’ll grab BCR shape file Birds Canada1. Add layer plot.  border cases bit hard separate visually. solve problem, can merge observations BCRs plot observations BCR well. First ’ll transform observation data match CRS bcr, ’ll join BCR information observations, based whether observations overlap BCR polygon (default left join). Now BCR designation observation. border cases now resolved.  might also interested observations time. First ’ll bin yearly observations ’ll also want see many sample years per decade. Now can see House Finch observations change years
code: canada <- ne_states(country = "canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   st_transform(3347)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) ab <- filter(canada, name == "Alberta")  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) download.file("https://birdscanada.org/download/gislab/bcr_terrestrial_shape.zip", "bcr_terrestrial_shape.zip") unzip("bcr_terrestrial_shape.zip") bcr <- st_read("BCR_Terrestrial/BCR_Terrestrial_master.shp") |>   filter(PROVINCE_S == "ALBERTA") |>   st_transform(3347) ## Reading layer `BCR_Terrestrial_master' from data source  ##   `/home/runner/work/naturecounts/naturecounts/vignettes/articles/BCR_Terrestrial/BCR_Terrestrial_master.shp'  ##   using driver `ESRI Shapefile' ## Simple feature collection with 373 features and 11 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -179.1413 ymin: 14.53287 xmax: 179.7785 ymax: 83.11063 ## Geodetic CRS:  NAD83 ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = factor(BCR)), alpha = 0.5, colour = NA) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(name = "BCR") house_finches_sf <- house_finches_sf |>   st_transform(st_crs(bcr)) |>   st_join(bcr) ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = factor(BCR)), alpha = 0.25, colour = NA) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, aes(fill = factor(BCR)), shape = 21) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(name = "BCR") house_finches_sf <- mutate(house_finches_sf,                             years = cut(survey_year,                                         breaks = seq(1960, 2010, 10),                                         labels = seq(1960, 2000, 10), right = FALSE)) years <- house_finches_sf |>   group_by(years) |>   summarize(n = length(unique(survey_year)), .groups = "drop") ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ab) +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = factor(BCR)), alpha = 0.5, colour = NA) +   geom_sf(data = house_finches_sf, size = 0.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(name = "BCR") +   geom_sf_text(data = years, x = 4427134, y = 2965275, hjust = 0, vjust = 1,                 aes(label = paste0("n = ", n))) +   facet_wrap(~years)

title: Mapping Observations
text: can also use naturecounts helper functions create presence/absence maps. download data RCBIOTABASE collection, make sure keep observations species location reported, create new presence column either TRUE, FALSE, NA sampling event. Finally use format_zero_fill() function fill sampling events cardinals (species_id 19360) detected (presence 0). bit convoluted, ’ll grab coordinates Sampling Event. necessary errors (worth reporting!) one lat/lon combo sampling event. Now presence/absence data cardinals, can create map.
code: cardinals <- nc_data_dl(collection = "RCBIOTABASE", username = "testuser",                          info = "nc_tutorial") ## Using filters: collections (RCBIOTABASE); fields_set (BMDE2.00-min) ## Collecting available records... ##    collection nrecords ## 1 RCBIOTABASE    12863 ## Total records: 12,863 ##  ## Downloading records for each collection: ##   RCBIOTABASE ##     Records 1 to 5000 / 12863 ##     Records 5001 to 10000 / 12863 ##     Records 10001 to 12863 / 12863 cardinals_zf <- cardinals |>   filter(AllSpeciesReported == "Yes", !is.na(latitude), !is.na(longitude)) |>   group_by(species_id, AllSpeciesReported, SamplingEventIdentifier) |>   summarize(presence = sum(as.numeric(ObservationCount)) > 0, .groups = "drop") |>   format_zero_fill(species = 19360, by = "SamplingEventIdentifier",                    fill = "presence") ##  - Converted 'fill' column (presence) from logical to numeric coords <- cardinals |>   select("SamplingEventIdentifier", "latitude", "longitude") |>   group_by(SamplingEventIdentifier, latitude, longitude) |>   mutate(n = n()) |>  # Count number of unique coordinates   group_by(SamplingEventIdentifier) |>   slice_max(n, with_ties = FALSE) |> # Grab the most common coordinates for each event   select(-"n")  cardinals_zf <- left_join(cardinals_zf, coords, by = "SamplingEventIdentifier")  head(cardinals_zf) ##   SamplingEventIdentifier species_id presence latitude longitude ## 1     RCBIOTABASE-10000-1      19360        0 45.58604 -77.48721 ## 2     RCBIOTABASE-10001-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 ## 3     RCBIOTABASE-10002-1      19360        0 45.50803 -77.50786 ## 4     RCBIOTABASE-10003-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 ## 5     RCBIOTABASE-10004-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 ## 6     RCBIOTABASE-10005-1      19360        0 45.51110 -77.50533 cnt <- st_as_sf(cardinals_zf, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   group_by(presence) |>   count(geometry)  ggplot() +   annotation_map_tile(type = "osm", zoomin = 0) +   geom_sf(data = cnt, aes(size = n, colour = factor(presence)), alpha = 0.5) +   scale_colour_manual(name = "Presence/Absence", values = c("#31688E", "#440154"),                        labels = c("1" = "Present", "0" = "Absent")) +   scale_size_continuous(name = "Number of Sampling Events", range = c(1, 20)) +   labs(caption = "Copyright OpenStreetMap contributors",        title = "Presence/Absence of Cardinals in the RCBIOTABASE collection") ## Zoom: 9 ## Fetching 16 missing tiles ##   | title: Exploring IBAs and BCRs
text: get visual idea different Important Bird Areas , let’s plot map Canada. First need grab IBA data frame convert spatial object. data contains lat/lon, assign CRS 4326 GPS lat/lon data, convert match crs maps.  want narrow one province, filter IBA data frame get limits Northwest Territories Put together  detailed view IBAs, can also grab shape files Birds Canada.  really explore areas, interactive maps can really useful. Note can move map, zoom , click specific IBAs information.
code: iba <- meta_iba_codes() |>   st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(3347)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) +   geom_sf(data = iba) iba_nwt <- filter(iba, statprov == "NT") limits <- st_bbox(filter(canada, name == "Northwest Territories")) ggplot() +    theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada) +   geom_sf(data = iba_nwt) +   geom_sf_text(data = iba_nwt, aes(label = iba_site), size = 3, vjust = -0.5) +   coord_sf(xlim = limits[c("xmin", "xmax")], ylim = limits[c("ymin", "ymax")]) iba <- st_read("https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:iba&outputFormat=application%2Fjson") |>   st_transform(3347) ## Reading layer `OGRGeoJSON' from data source  ##   `https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:iba&outputFormat=application%2Fjson'  ##   using driver `GeoJSON' ## Simple feature collection with 619 features and 7 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -141.2376 ymin: 41.67177 xmax: -52.66698 ymax: 78.10591 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 iba <- filter(iba, Status == "confirmed") # Omit historical areas  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = canada, colour = "grey80") +   geom_sf(data = iba, fill = "blue", colour = NA, show.legend = FALSE, alpha = 0.5) mapview(iba)

title: Exploring IBAs and BCRs
text: Bird Conservation Regions also available Birds Canada.  , interactive maps can really useful.
code: bcr <- st_read("https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:bcr&outputFormat=application%2Fjson") |>   st_transform(3347) ## Reading layer `OGRGeoJSON' from data source  ##   `https://birdmap.birdscanada.org/geoserver/atlas/ows?service=WFS&version=1.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=atlas:bcr&outputFormat=application%2Fjson'  ##   using driver `GeoJSON' ## Simple feature collection with 66 features and 3 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -179.1335 ymin: 14.54426 xmax: -52.54375 ymax: 83.14808 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = na, colour = "grey80") +   geom_sf(data = bcr, aes(fill = bcr), show.legend = FALSE, alpha = 0.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_c() mapview(bcr)

title: Region Codes
text: region must named list one following: country - Country code (e.g., CA Canada) statprov - State/province code (e.g., MB Manitoba) subnational2 - Subnational (type 2) code (e.g., CA.MB.07 Brandon Area) iba - Important Bird Areas (IBA) code (e.g., AB001 Beaverhill Lake Alberta) bcr - Bird Conservation Regions (e.g., 2 Western Alaska) utm_squares - UTM square code (e.g., 10UFE96 grid Alberta) bbox - Bounding box coordinates (e.g., c(left = -101.097223, bottom = 50.494717, right = -99.511239, top = 51.027557) box containing Riding Mountain National Park Manitoba) use region argument:
code: nc_count(region = list(statprov = "NB")) ## Without a username, using 'show = "all"' ## Using filters: statprov (NB) ## # A tibble: 84 × 4 ##    collection    akn_level access     nrecords ##    <chr>             <int> <chr>         <int> ##  1 ATOWLS                4 by request    15895 ##  2 BBS                   5 full          54578 ##  3 BBS50-CAN             5 full         207572 ##  4 CBC                   2 no access     21559 ##  5 EBIRD-CA-AT           4 by request  2373557 ##  6 EBIRD-CA-SENS         3 by request       94 ##  7 EBUTTERFLY            5 full           2393 ##  8 GBBC                  4 by request    12215 ##  9 GBIF_02DD359E         5 full            470 ## 10 GBIF_040C5662         5 full             43 ## # ℹ 74 more rows

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: ’ll using tidyverse packages dplyr ggplot2 data manipulation plotting, respectively. ’ll use gridExtra combine figures. ’ll use sf package working spatial data, rnaturalearth package get example spatial data. spatial data files like read R, recommend reading Reading, Writing Converting Simple Features Vignette sf website. First ’ll get spatial objects explorations rnaturalearth package. map Canada map Ontario, transformed CRS 4326 (unprojected lat/lon) 3347 (NAD83 Statistics Canada).  Alternatively specify groups inside ggplot()
code: library(naturecounts) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(patchwork) library(sf) library(rnaturalearth) na <- ne_countries(continent = "north america", returnclass = "sf") |>   st_transform(3347)  canada <- ne_states(country = "canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   st_transform(3347)  ontario <- ne_states(country = "Canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   filter(name == "Ontario") |>   st_transform(3347)  manitoba <- ne_states(country = "Canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   filter(name == "Manitoba") |>   st_transform(3347) ggplot() +    theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = canada) +                  # Map of Canada    geom_sf(data = ontario, fill = "orange")  # Map of Ontario ggplot() +    theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = canada, aes(fill = name == "Ontario"), show.legend = FALSE)+   scale_fill_manual(values = c("grey90", "orange"))

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: example, wanted collect public observations Winnipeg, Manitoba… Now ’ll get polygon representing Winnipeg, MB.  Looks like polygon Winnipeg doesn’t exactly match subnational2 area. ’s okay, ’ll filter match polygon:
code: search_region("winnipeg", type = "subnational2") ## # A tibble: 1 × 5 ##   country_code statprov_code subnational2_code subnational2_name                         ebird_code ##   <chr>        <chr>         <chr>             <chr>                                     <chr>      ## 1 CA           MB            CA.MB.11          Division No. 11 - Winnipeg Capital Region CA-MB-EL obs <- nc_data_dl(region = list(subnational2 = "CA.MB.11"),                    verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") winnipeg <- st_read("https://data.winnipeg.ca/resource/2nyq-f444.geojson") |>   st_transform(3347) ## Reading layer `2nyq-f444' from data source `https://data.winnipeg.ca/resource/2nyq-f444.geojson' using driver `GeoJSON' ## Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 1 field ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -97.34915 ymin: 49.71356 xmax: -96.95653 ymax: 49.99401 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 obs_sf <- st_as_sf(obs, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(3347)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = winnipeg) +   geom_sf(data = obs_sf) obs_sf <- st_join(obs_sf, distinct(winnipeg), left = FALSE)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = winnipeg) +   geom_sf(data = obs_sf)

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: following example, let’s assume wish concentrate observations urban areas Ontario, Canada. ’ll download data rnaturalearth package save working directory (“.”) Now ’ve saved , can load use. First ’ll transform 3347 CRS clip urban areas match borders Ontario (st_insection(spatial1, spatial2)). care geometry Ontario, data (st_geometry(ontario)).  Now filter observations urban areas, first step get UTM squares overlap areas. can collecting UTM squares meta_utm_squares() filtering include overlap urban areas.  ’s bit tricky see exactly ’s going , let’s zoom bit. However, ’s also bit tricky zoom ’re using non-lat/lon CRS units unintuitive. let’s specify limits want, transform CRS ’re using use set limits. convenience, ’ll use patchwork package combine figures side--side can get really good look ’re .  now can see utm_squares ’ve selected overlap urban areas. Now can download observations areas. can take time server process many utm_squares, ’ll increase timeout 5 minutes download couple utm squares. Finally, clip resulting observations exact urban areas:  However, sending large lists UTM squares can slow, consider using bounding box filtering downloaded data fact.
code: ne_download(scale = 10, type = "urban_areas", returnclass = "sf",              destdir = ".", load = FALSE) ## [1] "ne_10m_urban_areas" urban <- ne_load(scale = 10, type = "urban_areas", returnclass = "sf",                   destdir = ".") ## Reading layer `ne_10m_urban_areas' from data source  ##   `/tmp/RtmpCkWzFH/vignettes/region-spatial_files/ne_10m_urban_areas.shp' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' ## Simple feature collection with 11878 features and 4 fields ## Geometry type: POLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -157.9912 ymin: -51.05304 xmax: 178.0338 ymax: 69.76986 ## Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 urban_ontario <- urban |>   st_transform(3347) |>   st_intersection(st_geometry(ontario)) ## Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all geometries ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = ontario) +   geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "orange") utm_on <- meta_utm_squares() |>   filter(statprov_code == "ON") |>   st_transform(3347) |>  # Transform to match urban CRS   st_filter(urban_ontario)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = ontario) +   geom_sf(data = utm_on, fill = "red") +   geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) zoom <- data.frame(lon = c(-81, -78, -81, -78),                    lat = c(43, 43, 45, 45)) |>   st_as_sf(coords = c("lon", "lat"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(3347) |>   st_bbox() zoom ##      xmin      ymin      xmax      ymax  ## 7067507.7  830951.5 7352759.4 1101350.3 g1 <- ggplot() +     theme_bw() +      geom_sf(data = ontario) +     geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +     coord_sf(xlim = zoom[c(1,3)], ylim = zoom[c(2,4)])  g2 <- ggplot() +     theme_bw() +      geom_sf(data = ontario) +     geom_sf(data = utm_on, fill = "red", alpha = 0.5) +     geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +     coord_sf(xlim = zoom[c(1,3)], ylim = zoom[c(2,4)])  g1 + g2 obs <- nc_data_dl(region = list(utm_squares = utm_on$utm_square[1:10]),                    verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser", timeout = 300,                    info = "nc_vignette") obs_sf <- st_as_sf(obs, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326) |>   st_transform(crs = 3347) |>   st_join(distinct(urban_ontario), left = FALSE)  ggplot() +   theme_bw() +    geom_sf(data = ontario) +   geom_sf(data = urban_ontario, fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +   geom_sf(data = obs_sf, size = 1) +   coord_sf(xlim = zoom[c(1,3)], ylim = zoom[c(2,4)])

title: Using spatial data to filter observations
text: example, ’ll gather observations around Jasper Alberta. First ’ll define area want grab. Jasper 52.8755, -118.0833, want get bout lat lon around . Now ’ll get background map Alberta. Let’s see looks like.  Now can give coordinates directly nc_data_dl() function. Let’s take look…
code: jasper <- st_bbox(c(xmin = -118.0833 - 0.5,                      xmax = -118.0833 + 0.5,                      ymin = 52.8755 - 0.5,                     ymax = 52.8755 + 0.5),                    crs = 4326) alberta <- ne_states(country = "Canada", returnclass = "sf") |>   filter(name == "Alberta") ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = alberta) +   geom_sf(data = st_as_sfc(jasper), fill = "orange") obs <- nc_data_dl(region = list(bbox = jasper), verbose = FALSE, username = "testuser",                    info = "nc_vignette") ggplot() +   theme_bw() +   geom_sf(data = st_as_sfc(jasper), fill = "orange") +   geom_sf(data = st_as_sf(obs, coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326))

title: Selecting columns and fields to download

title: Species codes
text: simplest way determine species id (way, non-avian taxa) use search_species() function searches species id according scientific, English French name returns data frame taxonomic information related hits: species ids can used download data either directly: saving referencing data frame: might considered overkill single species, useful want download data multiple species:
code: search_species("moose") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name english_name french_name taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>           <chr>        <chr>       <chr>       #> 1     133990 Alces alces     Moose        NA          MAMMALS search_species("swallowtail") #> # A tibble: 8 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name     english_name            french_name taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>               <chr>                   <chr>       <chr>       #> 1     252492 Battus philenor     Pipevine Swallowtail    Papillon d… BUTTERFL    #> 2     252493 Eurytides marcellus Zebra Swallowtail       Papillon z… BUTTERFL    #> 3     252494 Papilio polyxenes   Black Swallowtail       Papillon d… BUTTERFL    #> 4     252495 Papilio machaon     Old World Swallowtail   Machaon     BUTTERFL    #> 5     252496 Papilio cresphontes Giant Swallowtail       Grand port… BUTTERFL    #> 6     252497 Papilio glaucus     Eastern Tiger Swallowt… Papillon t… BUTTERFL    #> 7     252498 Papilio canadensis  Canadian Tiger Swallow… Papillon t… BUTTERFL    #> 8     252499 Papilio troilus     Spicebush Swallowtail   Papillon c… BUTTERFL search_species("mesange a tete noire") #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name                english_name french_name taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>                          <chr>        <chr>       <chr>       #> 1      14280 Poecile atricapillus           Black-cappe… Mésange à … BIRDS       #> 2      40932 Poecile atricapillus x gambeli Black-cappe… Hybride Mé… BIRDS       #> 3      44462 Poecile atricapillus x hudson… Black-cappe… Hybride Mé… BIRDS       #> 4      44466 Poecile atricapillus x Baeolo… Black-cappe… Hybride Mé… BIRDS       #> 5      45746 Poecile atricapillus/gambeli   Black-cappe… Mésange à … BIRDS moose <- nc_data_dl(species = 133990, verbose = FALSE,                      username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") moose_id <- search_species("moose")$species_id moose <- nc_data_dl(species = moose_id, verbose = FALSE,                      username = "testuser", info = "nc_vignette") chickadee_ids <- search_species("chickadee") chickadee_ids  # title: Species codes
text: Taxonomy bird species long included various alphanumeric codes different taxonomic authorities. codes often include separate codes recognized subdivisions species (subspecies, subpopulations, hybrids, etc.). search_species_code() allows search avian species ids according authorities.

title: Species codes
text: default taxonomic authority used BSCDATA, uses 4-letter alpha codes: search function case insensitive: However, can search codes different authorities, specifying appropriate authority argument:
code: search_species_code("BCCH") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name      english_name           french_name     #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                <chr>                  <chr>           #> 1      14280 BCCH    Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee Mésange à tête… search_species_code("bcch") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name      english_name           french_name     #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                <chr>                  <chr>           #> 1      14280 BCCH    Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee Mésange à tête… search_species_code(8868, authority = "CBC") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id CBC   scientific_name      english_name           french_name       #>        <int> <chr> <chr>                <chr>                  <chr>             #> 1      14280 8868  Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee Mésange à tête n…

title: Species codes
text: default, search_species_codes() returns species ids related search term. example, searching myrtle warblers (MYWA), one two subspecies yellow-rumped warbler (YRWA) returns subspecies parent species. Note: Different taxonomic authorities recognize different subgroups. example, BSCDATA recognizes 4 groups dark-eyed juncos: Whereas CBC also recognizes sub group hybrids (Guadalupe junco): can search one authority time. Note search term needs match one authority (), information returned reflects authorities combined.
code: search_species_code("MYWA") #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name             english_name        french_name #>        <int> <chr>   <chr>                       <chr>               <chr>       #> 1      16610 YRWA    Setophaga coronata          Yellow-rumped Warb… Paruline à… #> 2      16620 MYWA    Setophaga coronata coronata Yellow-rumped Warb… Paruline à… #> 3      16630 AUWA    Setophaga coronata auduboni Yellow-rumped Warb… Paruline à… search_species_code("DEJU") #> # title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: Use nc_count() function return collections number observations access (returns collections associated username sample). Use show = "" argument show counts collections available (public otherwise).
code: nc_count(username = "sample") #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   collection akn_level access nrecords #>   <chr>          <int> <chr>     <int> #> 1 SAMPLE1            0 full        991 #> 2 SAMPLE2            0 full        995 nc_count(show = "all") %>%   head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   collection akn_level access     nrecords #>   <chr>          <int> <chr>         <int> #> 1 ABATLAS1           5 full         123364 #> 2 ABATLAS2           5 full         201357 #> 3 ABBIRDRECS         5 full         357264 #> 4 ATBANS             3 by request      267 #> 5 ATOWLS             4 by request    33964 #> 6 BBS                5 full        5735895

code: search_species("American Bittern") #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   species_id scientific_name       english_name     french_name      taxon_group #>        <int> <chr>                 <chr>            <chr>            <chr>       #> 1       2490 Botaurus lentiginosus American Bittern Butor d'Amérique BIRDS bittern <- nc_data_dl(species = 2490, username = "sample",                      info = "readme_example") #> Using filters: species (2490); fields_set (BMDE2.00-min) #> Collecting available records... #>   collection nrecords #> 1    SAMPLE1        1 #> Total records: 1 #>  #> Downloading records for each collection: #>   SAMPLE1 #>     Records 1 to 1 / 1 bittern <- nc_data_dl(species = 2490, sql_db = "bittern", username = "sample",                      info = "readme_example") #> Using filters: species (2490); fields_set (BMDE2.00-min) #> Collecting available records... #>   collection nrecords #> 1    SAMPLE1        1 #> Total records: 1 #>  #> Database 'bittern.nc' does not exist, creating it... #>  #> Downloading records for each collection: #>   SAMPLE1 #>     Records 1 to 1 / 1

code: nc_count(username = "my_user_name") bittern <- nc_data_dl(species = 2490, username = "my_user_name", info = "readme_example")

title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: nc_count() nc_data_dl() variety arguments allow filter counts/data prior downloading. options include collections, species, years, doy (day--year), region, site_type (users can specify 3 ). nc_data_dl() additional arguments fields_set fields can customize fields/columns include download. See function examples (nc_count(), nc_data_dl()) following articles information filters: Collections Species Codes Regional Codes IBAs BCRs (regions) Using spatial data filter observations also article post-filtering data

title: Access and download data on plant and animal populations from NatureCounts
text: NatureCounts includes great deal metadata can accessed functions meta_ prefix. See Meta Documentation specifics.

what: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Common arguments nc_data_dl nc_count

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: collections Character vector. collection codes download data. NULL (default) downloads data available collections project_ids Character/Numeric vector. project ids download data. First collections associated project_id determined, data downloaded collection. collections project_ids supplied, combined. species Numeric vector. Numeric species ids (see details) years Numeric vector. start/end years data download. Can use NA either start end, single value return data single year. doy Character/Numeric vector. start/end day--year download (1-366 dates can converted day year). Can use NA either start end region List. Named list one following options: country, statprov, subnational2, iba, bcr, utm_squares, bbox. See details site_type Character vector. type site return (e.g., IBA). username Character vector. Username http://naturecounts.ca. provided, user prompted password. left NULL, public collections returned. info Character vector. Short description reason download. E.g., "COSEWIC report", "Impact Assessment Study", "School project", etc. kind information helps NatureCounts.ca justify utility database. Required unless resuming/re-downloaded request_id. request_id Numeric. Specific request id check download. timeout Numeric. Number seconds connecting server times . verbose Logical. Show messages?

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: public data available username/password (sign free NatureCounts account). However, access private/semi-public projects/collections must request access. See Access request_ids section information.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Numeric species id codes can determined functions search_species() search_species_code(). See also article species codes information.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: format day year (doy) fairly flexible can whole number 1 366 anything recognized lubridate-package's ymd() function. However, must order year, month, day. Note year ignored converting day year, except result 1 day offset leap years.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Regions defined codes reflecting country, state/province, subnational (level 2), Important Bird Areas (IBA), Bird Conservation Regions (BCR) (see search_region() codes). can also defined providing specific UTM squares download bounding box area specifies min/max longitude min/max latitude (bbox). See article regional filters information.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: default data downloaded minimum set fields/columns. However, advanced applications, users may wish specify fields/columns return. Bird Monitoring Data Exchange (BMDE) schema keeps track variables used augment observation data. different versions reflecting different collections variables can specified download one four ways: fields_set can specific shorthand reflecting BMDE version: core, extended minimum (default). See meta_bmde_versions() see BMDE version shorthand refers . fields_set can default uses default BMDE version particular collection (note download one collection, field sets expand cover fields/columns combined collections) fields_set can exact BMDE version. See meta_bmde_versions() options. fields_set can custom fields argument can character vector specifying exact fields/columns return. See meta_bmde_fields()) potential fields values. Note cases set fields/columns always returned, matter fields_set used.

title: Common arguments for nc_data_dl and nc_count — args
text: Access data collection either available "full" "request". Use nc_count(username = "USER", show = ""), see accessibility collections. "Full" access means data can immediately requested directly naturecounts R package. "request" means request must submitted online approved data can downloaded naturecounts. means two types data requests: ones made naturecounts R package (API requests) made online Web Request Form (Web requests). Every request (either method) generates request_id identifies filter set collections requested. Details requests can reviewed nc_requests() function. download data "full" access, users can either specify filters, repeating download, can use request_id nc_requests(). Otherwise, user "full" access, must supply approved request_id nc_data_dl() function (e.g., nc_data_dl(request_id = 152000, username = "USER")). Use nc_requests() see request_ids, filters, approval status. Requests "full" access additional collections can made online Web Request Form checking "Full access?" box Step 2 form.

what: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: COSEWIC Index Area Occupancy (IAO; also called Area Occupancy, AOO IUCN) Extent Occurrence (EOO; IUCN well) metrics used support status assessments potentially endangered species.

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
code: cosewic_ranges(   df_db,   record = "record_id",   coord_lon = "longitude",   coord_lat = "latitude",   species = "species_id",   iao_grid_size_km = 2,   eoo_p = 0.95,   filter_unique = FALSE,   spatial = TRUE )

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: df_db Either data frame connection database naturecounts table. record Character. Name column containing record identification. coord_lon Character. Name column containing longitude. coord_lat Character. Name column containing latitude. species Character. Name column containing species identification. iao_grid_size_km Numeric. Size grid (km) use calculating IAO. Default COSEWIC requirement (2). Use caution changing. eoo_p Numeric. percentile calculate convex hull . Defaults 0.95 95% convex hull ensure outlier points artificially inflate EOO. Note final COSEWIC report, may appropriate. Set 1 include points. filter_unique Logical. Whether filter observations unique locations. Use many data points work . changes nature observation , also may bias EOO calculations using less 100% points (see eoo_p). spatial Logical. Whether return sf spatial objects showing calculations. FALSE (default) returns data frame IAO EOO values. TRUE returns list objects values spatial grid/polygons.

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: Summarized data frame (ranges) list containing ranges, summarized data frame, spatial, list two spatial data frames. ranges contains columns n_records_total - Total number records used create ranges min_record - Minimum number records within IAO cells max_record - Maximum number records within IAO cells median_record - Median number records within IAO cells grid_size_km - IAO cell size (area squared) n_occupied - Number IAO cells least one record iao - IAO value (grid_size_km^2 * n_occupied) eoo_pXX - EOO area calculated convex hull percentile eoo_p (e.g., 95%) spatial contains spatial data frames iao_sf - Polygons IAO grids n_records per cell eoo_sf - Polygon Convex Hull percentile eoo_p

title: Calculate COSEWIC IAO and EOO — cosewic_ranges
text: Note IUCN calls metric AOO, COSEWIC, AOO actually different measure, biological area occupancy. See Distribution section 'Instructions preparing COSEWIC status reports' details. default EOO calculated using inner 95% points (based distance centroid). ensure first-pass EOO reject species consideration outlier observations. However, final COSEWIC assessment report, likely better carefully explore data ensure outliers use full data set (.e. set eoo_p = 1). IAO calculated first assessing large grids (10x large specified size). smaller grids created within large grid cells containing observations. speeds process avoiding creation grids areas observations. means plots spatial objects may grids large areas lacking observations. See examples. Details IAO EOO calculated used COSEWIC - Guidelines use Index Area Occupancy COSEWIC Assessments COSEWIC - Instructions preparing COSEWIC status reports COSEWIC - Table 2 COSEWIC quantitative criteria guidelines status assessment Wildlife Species

title: Zero-fill data — format_zero_fill
code: # Download data (with "core" fields to include 'CommonName') sample <- nc_data_dl(collection = c("SAMPLE1", "SAMPLE2"), fields_set = "core",                      username = "sample", info = "nc_example") #> Using filters: collections (SAMPLE1, SAMPLE2); fields_set (BMDE2.00) #> Collecting available records... #>   collection nrecords #> 1    SAMPLE1      991 #> 2    SAMPLE2      995 #> Total records: 1,986 #>  #> Downloading records for each collection: #>   SAMPLE1 #>     Records 1 to 991 / 991 #>   SAMPLE2 #>     Records 1 to 995 / 995  # Remove casual observations (i.e. 'AllSpeciesReported' = "No") library(dplyr) # For filter function #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union sample <- filter(sample, AllSpeciesReported == "Yes")  # Remove data with "X" ObservationCount (only keep numeric obs) sample <- filter(sample, ObservationCount != "X")  # Zero fill by all species present sample_all_zeros <- format_zero_fill(sample) #>  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric  # Zero fill only for Canada Goose goose <- format_zero_fill(sample, species = "230") #>  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric  # Keep species-specific variables goose <- format_zero_fill(sample, species = "230", extra_species = "CommonName") #>  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric  # Keep sampling-event-specific variables coords <- format_zero_fill(sample, extra_event = c("latitude", "longitude")) #>  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric  # By species, keeping extra species variables and event variables goose_coords <- format_zero_fill(sample, species = "230",                                  extra_species = "CommonName",                                  extra_event = c("latitude", "longitude")) #>  - Converted 'fill' column (ObservationCount) from character to numeric  # Only return event information events <- format_zero_fill(sample, fill = NA,                            extra_event = c("latitude", "longitude"))

title: Download information about NatureCounts collections — nc_count
text: Access data collection either available "full" "request". Use nc_count(username = "USER", show = ""), see accessibility collections. "Full" access means data can immediately requested directly naturecounts R package. "request" means request must submitted online approved data can downloaded naturecounts. means two types data requests: ones made naturecounts R package (API requests) made online Web Request Form (Web requests). Every request (either method) generates request_id identifies filter set collections requested. Details requests can reviewed nc_requests() function. download data "full" access, users can either specify filters, repeating download, can use request_id nc_requests(). Otherwise, user "full" access, must supply approved request_id nc_data_dl() function (e.g., nc_data_dl(request_id = 152000, username = "USER")). Use nc_requests() see request_ids, filters, approval status. Requests "full" access additional collections can made online Web Request Form checking "Full access?" box Step 2 form.

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: Download data records various collections filtered various options. order ease load server, note three collections/project_ids, species, years, doy, region, site_type can used one request. See vignette filtering data download options: vignette("filtering_data", package = "naturecounts").

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
code: nc_data_dl(   collections = NULL,   project_ids = NULL,   species = NULL,   years = NULL,   doy = NULL,   region = NULL,   site_type = NULL,   fields_set = "minimum",   fields = NULL,   username,   info = NULL,   request_id = NULL,   sql_db = NULL,   warn = TRUE,   timeout = 120,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: collections Character vector. collection codes download data. NULL (default) downloads data available collections project_ids Character/Numeric vector. project ids download data. First collections associated project_id determined, data downloaded collection. collections project_ids supplied, combined. species Numeric vector. Numeric species ids (see details) years Numeric vector. start/end years data download. Can use NA either start end, single value return data single year. doy Character/Numeric vector. start/end day--year download (1-366 dates can converted day year). Can use NA either start end region List. Named list one following options: country, statprov, subnational2, iba, bcr, utm_squares, bbox. See details site_type Character vector. type site return (e.g., IBA). fields_set Character. Set fields/columns download. See details. fields Character vector. fields_set = custom, fields/columns download. See details username Character vector. Username http://naturecounts.ca. provided, user prompted password. left NULL, public collections returned. info Character vector. Short description reason download. E.g., "COSEWIC report", "Impact Assessment Study", "School project", etc. kind information helps NatureCounts.ca justify utility database. Required unless resuming/re-downloaded request_id. request_id Numeric. Specific request id check download. sql_db Character vector. Name location SQLite database either create add warn Logical. Interactive warning request 1,000,000 records download. timeout Numeric. Number seconds connecting server times . verbose Logical. Show messages?

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: Data frame connection SQLite database

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: public data available username/password (sign free NatureCounts account). However, access private/semi-public projects/collections must request access. See Access request_ids section information.

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: Numeric species id codes can determined functions search_species() search_species_code(). See also article species codes information.

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: format day year (doy) fairly flexible can whole number 1 366 anything recognized lubridate-package's ymd() function. However, must order year, month, day. Note year ignored converting day year, except result 1 day offset leap years.

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: Regions defined codes reflecting country, state/province, subnational (level 2), Important Bird Areas (IBA), Bird Conservation Regions (BCR) (see search_region() codes). can also defined providing specific UTM squares download bounding box area specifies min/max longitude min/max latitude (bbox). See article regional filters information.

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: default data downloaded minimum set fields/columns. However, advanced applications, users may wish specify fields/columns return. Bird Monitoring Data Exchange (BMDE) schema keeps track variables used augment observation data. different versions reflecting different collections variables can specified download one four ways: fields_set can specific shorthand reflecting BMDE version: core, extended minimum (default). See meta_bmde_versions() see BMDE version shorthand refers . fields_set can default uses default BMDE version particular collection (note download one collection, field sets expand cover fields/columns combined collections) fields_set can exact BMDE version. See meta_bmde_versions() options. fields_set can custom fields argument can character vector specifying exact fields/columns return. See meta_bmde_fields()) potential fields values. Note cases set fields/columns always returned, matter fields_set used.

title: Download NatureCounts data records — nc_data_dl
text: Access data collection either available "full" "request". Use nc_count(username = "USER", show = ""), see accessibility collections. "Full" access means data can immediately requested directly naturecounts R package. "request" means request must submitted online approved data can downloaded naturecounts. means two types data requests: ones made naturecounts R package (API requests) made online Web Request Form (Web requests). Every request (either method) generates request_id identifies filter set collections requested. Details requests can reviewed nc_requests() function. download data "full" access, users can either specify filters, repeating download, can use request_id nc_requests(). Otherwise, user "full" access, must supply approved request_id nc_data_dl() function (e.g., nc_data_dl(request_id = 152000, username = "USER")). Use nc_requests() see request_ids, filters, approval status. Requests "full" access additional collections can made online Web Request Form checking "Full access?" box Step 2 form.

new site #> 2            2          0      0 Changed sites in spring in 2006 - new site #> 3            3          0      0 Changed sites in spring in 2006 - new site #> 4            4          0      0 Changed sites in spring in 2006 - new site #> 5            5          0      0 Changed sites in spring in 2006 - new site #> 6            6          0      0 Changed sites in spring in 2006 - new site #> 7            0          0      0              Oak Hammock Marsh covid dates #>   project_id SiteCode survey_year start_year end_year survey_day #> 1       1005     DMBO           0          0     2005          0 #> 2       1005     DMBO           0          0     2005          0 #> 3       1005     DMBO           0          0     2005          0 #> 4       1005     DMBO           0          0     2005          0 #> 5       1005     DMBO           0          0     2005          0 #> 6       1005     DMBO           0          0     2005          0 #> 7       1005     DMBO        2020          0        0          0  # Filter our query d <- nc_query_table(table = "bmde_filter_bad_dates",                     species_id = 15770, username = "sample")                      # Want more than one species? Either filter after, or combine two queries  # Filter after library(dplyr) d <- nc_query_table(table = "bmde_filter_bad_dates", username = "sample") d <- filter(d, species_id %in% c(15770, 9750))  # Combine two queries d1 <- nc_query_table(table = "bmde_filter_bad_dates",                      species_id = 15770, username = "sample") d2 <- nc_query_table(table = "bmde_filter_bad_dates",                      species_id = 9750, username = "sample") d <- rbind(d1, d2)

title: Check on status of data requests — nc_requests
text: request_id Numeric. Specific request id check download. type Character One "web", "api", "" specifying types request return (defaults "web"). username Character vector. Username http://naturecounts.ca. provided, user prompted password. left NULL, public collections returned.

title: Check on status of data requests — nc_requests
text: data frame

title: Check on status of data requests — nc_requests
text: Access data collection either available "full" "request". Use nc_count(username = "USER", show = ""), see accessibility collections. "Full" access means data can immediately requested directly naturecounts R package. "request" means request must submitted online approved data can downloaded naturecounts. means two types data requests: ones made naturecounts R package (API requests) made online Web Request Form (Web requests). Every request (either method) generates request_id identifies filter set collections requested. Details requests can reviewed nc_requests() function. download data "full" access, users can either specify filters, repeating download, can use request_id nc_requests(). Otherwise, user "full" access, must supply approved request_id nc_data_dl() function (e.g., nc_data_dl(request_id = 152000, username = "USER")). Use nc_requests() see request_ids, filters, approval status. Requests "full" access additional collections can made online Web Request Form checking "Full access?" box Step 2 form.

title: Fetch authorization token — srv_auth

title: Fetch authorization token — srv_auth
code: srv_auth(username)

title: Fetch authorization token — srv_auth
text: username Character vector. Username http://naturecounts.ca. provided, user prompted password. left NULL, public collections returned.

title: Fetch authorization token — srv_auth
text: Token character string

title: Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: sym() creates symbol string syms() creates list symbols character vector. expr() quo() quote one expression. quo() wraps quoted expression quosure. plural variants rlang::exprs() quos() return list quoted expressions quosures. enexpr() enquo() capture expression supplied argument user current function (enquo() wraps expression quosure). enexprs() enquos() capture multiple expressions supplied arguments, including .... exprs() exported avoid conflicts Biobase::exprs(), therefore one always use rlang::exprs(). learn tidy eval use tools, visit http://rlang.r-lib.org Metaprogramming section Advanced R.
